stories.title: LVars: Lattice-Based Data Structures for Deterministic Parallelism [pdf]

stories.text:
As I write this post, my neighbors from above, probably college students, are having a party of their lifetime, laughing, kicking and screaming. I'm not even mad at them, just full of envy.

The last time I had fun like this was in college. I was broke, renting a big flat with a bunch of roommates, but young, healthy, and full of enthusiasm (and booze). Finding friends in my teens and 20s was as easy as going out literally anywhere.

When I went to work work, I thought my life would only get better. I worked from home, and I was paid so well, that I kept pushing overtime because if felt too good to last. I made a good career, but in the process, quickly drifted off into a complete isolation.

These days I still either work from home, or at best with a bunch of other devs in a mostly empty office. I tried to meet new people at hobbies and dance lessons, but guess what - they're all full of lonely developers and other socially awkward people - short guys looking for girlfriends, unattractive/aging women looking for husbands, etc.

All the "normal" people I knew in the past are now changing diapers and working to pay off their mortgages, which I guess is a kind of consolation. Still, I'm only in my 30s, and it feels like my life is pretty much done. Doing things by myself is boring and depressing, and a getting into a group of "normal" friends, of both genders, to hang out and laugh with, seems like an impossible goal.

Nevertheless, in case someone has any advice beyond finding a hobby and going to therapy, it would be appreciated. Otherwise, maybe someone will at least take this as a cautionary tale to cultivate your social groups while you're young. Later it just gets exponentially harder to find them.
stories.title: Ask HN: At a peak of my dev career, I hate my life

stories.text: I'm working on a project and i'm at a step where there are several options for accomplishing the task, any of them working will do. And because I really don't care which of them I use, I try to find which of them will take the least effort/time to get working. But i've found myself trapped in a cycle: Every time I dig a little deeper into one solution, I find something that looks like it'd be unpleasant to deal with and I switch over to inspecting a different solution (e.g. browsing through a different library.) I've looped a few times now between three reasonable routes, getting a little deeper in each one each time. Does anyone else ever get caught in this kind of cycle?
stories.title: Ask HN: Is there a name for this behavioral phenomenon?

stories.text:
Hello fellow hackers,

I recently watched the oft-referenced Line Goes Up video[1] and basically ate it up. That being said, I know that that HN leans anti-Crypto and I want to make an effort to not be in an echo chamber. I saw some critical comments on other threads[2][3], but I was hoping to start this thread with the explicit goal of discussing the limitations and oversights of the video.

All input and perspectives are welcome, thank you!

[1] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YQ_xWvX1n9g&t=5455s [2] https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=30120437 [3] https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=30049130
stories.title: Ask HN: Criticisms of Line Goes Up?
